definition: A fundamental principle in civil procedure (弁論主義) dictating that the collection and introduction of factual materials (facts and evidence) are primarily the responsibility of the parties, not the court. The court must generally base its judgment only on facts alleged and materials submitted by the parties.
japaneseDefinition: 民事訴訟における基本原則の一つで、裁判所は当事者が主張し提出した事実及び証拠のみを裁判の基礎としなければならないとするもの。
japaneseWordTranslation: 弁論主義 (べんろんしゅぎ)
legalContext: Derived from core concepts of the Japanese Civil Procedure Code, often interpreted in conjunction with provisions concerning evidence submission (e.g., CPC Art. 156).
japaneseLegalContext: 民事訴訟法の基本理念から導かれ、証拠提出に関する規定（例：民事訴訟法第156条）と密接に関連付けられる。
exampleSentence: The judge dismissed the plaintiff's argument because the factual basis, though known to the judge privately, had not been formally introduced under the Principle of Party Presentation.
exampleTranslation: 裁判官が個人的に知っていた事実的根拠であっても、弁論主義に基づき正式に提出されていなかったため、裁判官は原告の主張を棄却した。
